xxl.core.collections.queues
Class DecoratorQueue<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.queues.DecoratorQueue<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements of this queue.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Queue<E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
AbstractMemoryManageableQueue, BoundedQueue, DistinctQueue, ThreadsafeQueue, UnmodifiableQueue
public abstract class DecoratorQueue<E>
extends Object
implements Queue<E>

This class provides a decorator for a queue that follows the Decorator Design Pattern (for further details see Structural Patterns, Decorator in Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software by Erich Gamma, Richard Helm, Ralph Johnson, and John Vlissides). It provides a more flexible way to add functionality to a queue or one of its subclasses as by inheritance.

To provide this functionality the class contains a reference to the queue to be decorated. This reference is used to redirect method calls to the original queue. This class is an abstract class although it provides no abstract methods. That's so because it does not make any sense to instanciate this class which redirects every method call to the corresponding method of the decorated queue without adding any functionality.

Usage example (1). 

     // create a new decorated queue that adds functionality to the enqueue method 
     // and leaves the other methods untouched

     DecoratorQueue queue = new DecoratorQueue(new ListQueue()) {
         public void enqueue (Object object) {

             // every desired functionality can be added to this method

             System.out.println("Before the insertion of the specified object!");
             super.enqueue(object);
             System.out.println("After the insertion of the specified object!");
         }
     }

See Also:
Queue

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a new DecoratorQueue (see contract for FACTORY_METHOD in interface Queue). In contradiction to the contract in Queue it may only be invoked with an array (parameter list) (for further details see Function) of queues. The array (parameter list) will be used to initialize the decorated queue. This field is set to UnmodifiableQueue.FACTORY_METHOD.

See Also:
Function

queue

protected Queue<E> queue
A reference to the queue to be decorated. This reference is used to perform method calls on the original queue.

isOpened

protected boolean isOpened
Internally used to store the state of this queue (if it is opened).

isClosed

protected boolean isClosed
Internally used to store the state of this queue (if it is closed).

Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the queue, i.e., signals the queue to reserve resources, open files, etc. Before a queue has been opened calls to methods like peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a queue's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the queue remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed queue usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Queue<E>

close

public void close()
Closes this queue and releases any system resources associated with it. This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method take the same effect as a single call.
Note: This method is very important for queues using external resources like files or JDBC resources.

Specified by:
close in interface Queue<E>

enqueue

public void enqueue(E object)
             throws IllegalStateException
Appends the specified element to the end of this queue. The end of the queue is given by its strategy.

Specified by:
enqueue in interface Queue<E>
Parameters:
object - element to be appended at the end of this queue.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the queue is already closed when this method is called.

peek

public E peek()
       throws IllegalStateException,
              NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the queue without removing it. The next element of the queue is given by its strategy.

Specified by:
peek in interface Queue<E>
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:

dequeue

public E dequeue()
          throws IllegalStateException,
                 NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the queue and removes it. The next element of the queue is given by its strategy.

isEmpty

public boolean isEmpty()
Returns false if the queue has more elements (in other words, returns false if next would return an element rather than throwing an exception).

Specified by:
isEmpty in interface Queue<E>
Returns:

size

public int size()
Returns the number of elements in this queue. If this queue contains more than Integer.MAX_VALUE elements, returns Integer.MAX_VALUE.

Specified by:
size in interface Queue<E>
Returns:
the number of elements in this queue.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all of the elements from this queue. The queue will be empty after this call returns so that size() == 0.
Note that the elements will only be removed from the queue but not from the underlying collection.

Specified by:
clear in interface Queue<E>
